Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multi-Accuracy Bayesian Models for Improving Property Prediction of Nanotube Buckypaper Composites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research between Florida State University and Texas A&M University is to develop multi-accuracy predictive models that can enhance the prediction capability for bukypaper-based composite properties. The team will investigate proper modeling strategies to integrate the multi-accuracy information as well as the solution techniques that address the associated computational and design issues in order to guarantee the method's efficiency and practicality. Currently, a few mechanics models are available for making property predictions for bukypaper-based composites but most of them suffer from having low accuracy due to model inadequacy and uncertainty. The outputs from the mechanics models and actual physical experiments constitute a set of multi-accuracy information sources, reflecting the same physical properties from different perspectives. Our conjecture is that combining the multi-accuracy outputs could help enhance the desired property predication for bukypaper-based composites.

The successful development of this new methodology will potentially enable stable, repeatable, and scalable production processes for bukypaper-based composites, which are one of the most sought-after nano-materials, due to its properties unfound in traditional materials and applicability to a broad array of applications. The High-Performance Material Institute (HPMI) at Florida State University, with which the lead PI is affiliated, is one of the best research facilities in the nation in terms of buckypaper R&D and prototype production capabilities. Predictive models are the cornerstones for enabling any attempts of process and quality control in nano-manufacturing because only with these models can people identify the critical process variables for taking in-process measurements, or making adjustments, in order to yield expected outcomes.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since discovered in 1991, carbon nanotubes have been the focus of significant research due to their exceptional material properties. One method of making use of carbon nanotubes is to first make buckypapers, a freestanding thin film of inter-digitated nanotubes with thickness of 10 - 25 microns and then make composites using the resulting buckypapers and polymer resin. It has been demonstrated that the buckypapers-based new composite materials could significantly enhance multi-functionality (electrical, mechanical and thermal) of the resulting material, thereby having great potentials to impact next-generation manufacturing as well as the application industries (for instance, as new materials for aircraft fuselages or wind turbine blades).

With this great potential, an intense interest is to be able to predict certain property of a resulting buckypapers-based composite material by taking clues from certain process parameters. The technical objective of this NSF-funded research is to develop a modeling and analysis framework, based on multi-accuracy data sources or multi-fidelity models, for improving the capability of making material property prediction and reducing the cost and cycle time of material design/manufacturing processes by cutting down unnecessary physical experiments.  The research team improved the physics-based simulation models, also known as computer experiments, and simulated the material properties that have decent degree of correlation with the physical experimental outputs. The use of computer experiments is an important element in reducing the cost and cycle time of design and manufacturing processes. But the outputs from computer experiments are not at the same quality level as those from physical experiments. Subsequent researches were conducted to develop multi-fidelity strategies that combine the strength of individual models and overcome their respective shortcomings.

This is a multi-university research project, led by Dr. Chuck (Chun) Zhang, initially at Florida State University and later relocated to Georgia Institute of Technology, collaborating with Dr. Yu Ding at Texas A&M University (TAMU). This report summarizes the outcome of the research efforts led by TAMU, as follows:

(a) TAMU team investigated different multi-accuracy and multi-fidelity modeling strategies.  The team discovered that in making the buckypapers, certain process conditions exist but they may not be directly observable.  These variables are labeled as latent variables, namely, hidden variables.  The research team developed new modeling and solution techniques to solve the multi-accuracy/multi-fidelity models with the presence of latent variables.

(b) TAMU team developed computationally competitive solution methods that can handle a large number of simulated data (physically datasets are usually small). The team explored two different approaches.  The first is a divide-and-conquer strategy that partitions the input space into smaller pieces and then handles each smaller problem individually. The second approach, labeled as Bayesian site selection, is an adaptive searching strategy, which can intelligently select a much smaller subset of the original data samples for prediction purpose without sacrificing too much the predictive capability.

 (c) TAMU team studied a sequential design strategy that provides intelligent guidance on data collection, especially from the more expensive physical experiment-based data collection. The sequential strategy starts with a small, and thus affordable, amount of physical experimental data and then rely on the low-fidelity (and therefore low-cost) computer experiment outputs to look for the best location to collect the next physical data sample.  The strategy embeds a stopping criterion that terminates the data collection process when any marginal increase in m...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Since discovered in 1991, carbon nanotubes have been the focus of significant research due to their exceptional material properties. One method of making use of carbon nanotubes is to first make buckypapers, a freestanding thin film of inter-digitated nanotubes with thickness of 10 - 25 microns and then make composites using the resulting buckypapers and polymer resin. It has been demonstrated that the buckypapers-based new composite materials could significantly enhance multi-functionality (electrical, mechanical and thermal) of the resulting material, thereby having great potentials to impact next-generation manufacturing as well as the application industries (for instance, as new materials for aircraft fuselages or wind turbine blades). With this great potential, an intense interest is to be able to predict certain property of a resulting buckypapers-based composite material by taking clues from certain process parameters. The technical objective of this NSF-funded research is to develop a modeling and analysis framework, based on multi-accuracy data sources or multi-fidelity models, for improving the capability of making material property prediction and reducing the cost and cycle time of material design/manufacturing processes by cutting down unnecessary physical experiments. The research team improved the physics-based simulation models, also known as computer experiments, and simulated the material properties that have decent degree of correlation with the physical experimental outputs. The use of computer experiments is an important element in reducing the cost and cycle time of design and manufacturing processes. But the outputs from computer experiments are not at the same quality level as those from physical experiments. Subsequent researches were conducted to develop multi-fidelity strategies that combine the strength of individual models and overcome their respective shortcomings. This is a multi-university research project, led by Dr. Chuck (Chun) Zhang, initially at Florida State University and later relocated to Georgia Institute of Technology, collaborating with Dr. Yu Ding at Texas A&M University (TAMU). This report summarizes the outcome of the research efforts led by TAMU, as follows: (a) TAMU team investigated different multi-accuracy and multi-fidelity modeling strategies. The team discovered that in making the buckypapers, certain process conditions exist but they may not be directly observable. These variables are labeled as latent variables, namely, hidden variables. The research team developed new modeling and solution techniques to solve the multi-accuracy/multi-fidelity models with the presence of latent variables. (b) TAMU team developed computationally competitive solution methods that can handle a large number of simulated data (physically datasets are usually small). The team explored two different approaches. The first is a divide-and-conquer strategy that partitions the input space into smaller pieces and then handles each smaller problem individually. The second approach, labeled as Bayesian site selection, is an adaptive searching strategy, which can intelligently select a much smaller subset of the original data samples for prediction purpose without sacrificing too much the predictive capability. (c) TAMU team studied a sequential design strategy that provides intelligent guidance on data collection, especially from the more expensive physical experiment-based data collection. The sequential strategy starts with a small, and thus affordable, amount of physical experimental data and then rely on the low-fidelity (and therefore low-cost) computer experiment outputs to look for the best location to collect the next physical data sample. The strategy embeds a stopping criterion that terminates the data collection process when any marginal increase in model capability no long justifies the cost and effort of collecting additional data points.
